div1.p: The editor praises the work of Reed, Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte as having laid the foundation for all future efforts against yellow fever and malaria. Carroll is singled out for commendation and called a martyr.

div1.head: Editorial from the Military Surgeon, [19--]
div1.p:
Editorial in the Military Surgeon-
Appeal for Major James Carroll's Family

In Dr. Goldberger's excellent monograph on Yellow Fever the work of the
Army Board in Cuba, headed by Major Walter Reed, is stated in a single pithy
sentence. Referring to the conveyance of the yellow fever infection by mos-
quitos he says that it converted a discredited hypothesis into an established
doctrine. This key unlocked the gate which has lead us into a wide field of
sanitary accomplishment. The epoch-making victory over yellow fever of Gorgas
in Havana; his sanitary regeneration of the Isthmus, White's brilliant results
in the New Orleans epidemic of 1905, and Kean's recent extensive campaign in
Cuba are all the direct fruits of the demonstration of Finlay's theory by the
work of Reed, Lazear, Carroll and Agramonte in 1900. By a singular fatality
this gallant band have, with a single exception, all perished in the prime of
their vigor and usefulness. Dr. Agramonte, the sole survivor, is a disting-
uished member of the faculty of the ancient University of Havana and a valued
adviser of the Sanitary Department of Cuba. The rewards which these soldiers
of science received during their lives was little or nothing. All left
families without adequate means of support, altho their widows are now in re-
ceipt of pensions which keep the wolf from the door indeed, but without any
broad margin for even Spartan luxuries. The attention of our readers is
called to an appeal on page of this number of the Journal which calls
attention to the necessities of the family of Major James Carroll, who are
threatened with the loss of their home by the foreclosure of a mortgage and
are in need of immediate assistance. Major Carroll, it will be recalled,
was the first volunteer to suffer an experimental attack of yellow fever by
having submitted to the bite of an infected mosquito. This attack was so
severe as to very seriously endanger his life and left him with a dilated
- 2 -
heart which was the ultimate cause of his death. He thus died a martyr of
science, and the medical profession of America will surely not turn a deaf
ear to the plea for assistance in the effort to secure a roof over the heads
of the large and dependent family which he left behind him.
